message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lymphoma, and the presence of lymphocytes with a high proliferative index that stain positive for CD20 point towards Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Burkitt lymphoma and Adult T-cell lymphoma usually involve fewer lymph nodes, while Hodgkin lymphoma typically presents with painless lymphadenopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest lymphoma, and the analysis of the excised cervical lymph node supports the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Burkitt lymphoma is rare in adults, and Adult T-cell lymphoma and Hodgkin lymphoma would have different histological features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest lymphoma, which is confirmed by the excised cervical lymph node analysis. Among the options, Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is associated with rapidly progressive lymphadenopathy and extranodal sites of involvement. Burkitt lymphoma primarily occurs in children and young adults and is associated with involvement of the jaw and abdominal organs. Adult T-cell lymphoma is associated with human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 infection and affects primarily Japan and the Caribbean. Hodgkin lymphoma is associated with Reed-Sternberg cells and typically present with localized lymphadenopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms point towards lymphoma, especially with the presence of enlarged lymph nodes, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue. The presence of CD20 positive lymphocytes indicates a B-cell lymphoma, and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is the most common type of B-cell lymphoma in adults. Burkitt lymphoma is more commonly seen in children and is associated with jaw and abdominal involvement. Hodgkin lymphoma usually presents with painless lymphadenopathy and is often associated with Reed-Sternberg cells in the lymph nodes. Adult T-cell lymphoma is associated with a viral infection and is more commonly seen in Japan and the Caribbean.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings are suggestive of lymphoma, which is confirmed by the excised cervical lymph node showing lymphocytes with a high proliferative index that stain positive for CD20. Among the options, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and has a similar presentation to the patient's. Burkitt lymphoma is more common in children and young adults and is characterized by rapidly growing tumors in the abdomen or pelvis. Hodgkin lymphoma typically presents with painless lymphadenopathy and B symptoms and is differentiated from DLBCL based on specific histopathological findings. Adult T-cell lymphoma is associated with human T-lymphotropic virus-1 infection and is more common in Asia and Africa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and findings suggest a diagnosis of a B-cell lymphoma, and among the options, Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is the most likely as it is the most common type of aggressive lymphoma in adults. The high proliferative index and positive staining for CD20 support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the lymph node biopsy suggest diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Burkitt lymphoma presents as a rapidly growing mass in the abdomen, while Hodgkin lymphoma usually presents with multiple, painless, enlarged lymph nodes. Adult T-cell lymphoma is associated with the human T-lymphotropic virus and presents with skin lesions and hypercalcemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including fatigue, abdominal pain, night sweats, and weight loss, are associated with lymphoma. The CT scan and lymph node biopsy confirm lymphoma, and the positive CD20 staining indicates B-cell lymphoma. Among the options, only Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma fits these findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination, and CT scan findings suggest lymphoma. The high proliferative index and positive CD20 stain are specific to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Hodgkin lymphoma may also present with supraclavicular lymph node enlargement, but it is unlikely given the negative findings on the biopsy. Adult T-cell lymphoma and Burkitt lymphoma typically present with more aggressive symptoms and a faster onset.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of lymphoma, and the presence of enlarged, fixed lymph nodes and the positive CD20 staining suggest Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Burkitt lymphoma and Adult T-cell lymphoma are less likely based on the presentation. Hodgkin lymphoma could also be a possibility, but the absence of Reed-Sternberg cells on lymph node biopsy is more supportive of Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.
